sub_topic: Finding the magnitude and direction of a vector using trigonometry.
message_1: A force vector with a magnitude of 20 N is acting at an angle of 60 degrees with the positive x-axis. Find the magnitude and direction of the vector in terms of i and j unit vectors.
message_2:
To find the magnitude and direction of the force vector in terms of i and j unit vectors, we need to break the vector into its horizontal (x) and vertical (y) components. We can do this using trigonometry.

The horizontal component (x) can be found using the cosine function:
Fx = magnitude * cos(angle)
Fx = 20 N * cos(60°)

The vertical component (y) can be found using the sine function:
Fy = magnitude * sin(angle)
Fy = 20 N * sin(60°)

First, we need to convert the angle from degrees to radians:
60° * (π/180) = (1/3)π radians

Now, we can find the x and y components:
Fx = 20 N * cos((1/3)π) = 20 N * (1/2) = 10 N
Fy = 20 N * sin((1/3)π) = 20 N * (√3/2) = 10√3 N

So, the force vector can be represented in terms of i and j unit vectors as:
F = 10i + 10√3j N
